captions.text:
- Don't you have a job
interview on Monday?
- Yeah, I do.

- Aren't you going to
straighten your hair?
- Mom, can we not, not do this today?
- Oh, my God, what kind of job do you-

- Hey, sorry I'm late, my hair
was so nappy this morning.
- Hey Jodie, you met Tracy?
- Um, no, I don't think so.
- Yeah, she's got the wild and crazy hair
I was telling you about.

- I really don't think
they're going to be hiring you
with your hair looking all wild like that.

- Ah! Do you know who
you look like? Solange.
- You know, I remember back in my day,
you know, you couldn't even walk into a-
- Oh my God, did you cut your hair?
- I love this new, like, black bohemian

hipster thing you've been
doing with your afro.
- No, no, no, no, no, Macy Gray.
- I know you're into this natural movement

and then you're all into this
radical revolutionary stuff.
- It's so trendy.
- Who do you think you are, Angela Davis?
- No, no, Foxy Cleopatra, shazam!

- So have you ever
straighten your hair before?
- Do you wash your hair?
- I think it'd look really cute on you.
- Can I touch?
- No.

- Your hair looks so different
every time I see you.
- Please?
- No.
- Can I please touch?
- No.

- Can you even get a
comb through this bush?
- Mom!

- I don't even know if
it's you half the time.
- You just, you don't look at my face?
- See, you running your hands through it
is like, messing up-

- Running? You think I'm
running my hands through this?
- It's so crazy every time.
- It's like a pillow.

- Can't even walk through
your hair, skip, nothin'.
- I want to sleep in it.
- It's confusing for me.
- Oh, hey.

- I just don't understand why
you stopped perming your hair.

- You looked so good
with your hair permed.

- I've never really been
a clementine guy before.

- That's just so unique
and exotic. It's just...
What? It's so voluminous and rich and...
- Yeah, I wouldn't. I wouldn't.
- It's just tall.
- I'd stop. I would just stop.

- Tracy, your hair is so big
and wild like a lion, you know?

title: Things Women With Natural Hair Are Tired Of Hearing

comments.text: OMG SOMEONE THOUGHT NY HAIR WAS WEAVE BEFORE..... 😒﻿
comments.author: Jay Bae

comments.text:
"Into this natural movement"..... You do realize that's how our hair 
naturally grows right?﻿

comments.text: This literally never happens﻿
comments.author: Anna Todd

comments.text: I love her nirvana shirt ﻿

comments.text: lol, the last one killed me﻿

comments.text: +Jimeia Roberts﻿

comments.text: Bahaha what? ﻿
comments.author: ParanormalPandasInc

comments.text:
Ugh I hate the reaching for my hair, like no one should believe "oh it has

comments.author: Tati Kagnassy

comments.text:
In high school, I used to occasionally wear my hair in ringlets (I'm mixed, 
and if I wrap it around my fingers, it will dry that way. It looks like a 
wig). I once landed myself in the principal's office because some girl kept 
reaching for my hair, and I got in trouble for telling her to stop. My 
teacher told me to stop talking in class. She reached for my hair again, 
and I turned and quickly bit at her fingers. She screamed and pulled her 
hand back. I told the principal I was simply following instructions not to 
speak, and she was making my hair all frizzy by pulling on it, as well as 
invading my personal space. I got sent home for it and she never reached 
for my hair again. I regret nothing.﻿
comments.author: EmileeArsenic

comments.text: Yes! Everyday﻿

comments.text:
why is everyone like: why is it just black girls, other girls have natural

black girl hair or super curly hair thats how it is yeah eveyone has 
natural hair but these days "natural hair" is refering to black girls dont

comments.text:
Whoa so many ignorant people commenting. Are y'all even thinking before you 
type? (That was rhetorical) Hair is not just hair. People of African 
descent tend to have a unique texture of hair, other nationalities just 
can't compare. I'm Black but I know non-black people hair routines. There 
are jillions of videos right on the youtube, educate yourself before you 
starting getting offended. Back in the days Black actresses couldn't wear 
an afro on television. It was that serious. Heck, It still is!﻿

Not even just women. I have the Troy Polamalu hair and people always say

Another thing is people saying, "wow, your hair is so thick!" It's not

I get asked this everyday!!!! People want to stroke my hair they ask why

This is actually the kind of video where "black" women would be okay to put

comments.text:
I have curly hair and people always ask, "Do you curl it?", "Can I touch

comments.author: Rhea Griffin

comments.text:
Also now that my curls are tight, bouncy and pretty, I wear it natural to 
school more often. And no matter how many times these people see my hair, 
black or white, they wanna touch it! It gets annoying cuz sometimes they 
don't ask, and even if they do I don't want them to. I feel kinda like a 
special little flower sometimes though. I like the the fact that no one 
else has hair like mine in the high school (I'm pretty sure). Not really 
accomplishing much though cuz I go to a small school. (btw I'm Dominican)﻿
comments.author: Jailyn Feliz

comments.text:
I hate it when white people say their hair is nappy! Like my curls are 
better and easier to comb now cuz puberty did me a huge favor but when I 
was younger my hair was so hard to manage. Most of the time my hair was 
straight cuz my mom made me but when some white girls said their hair was 
nappy, I sat there thinking "you have no idea what you're talking about, 
your hair isn't capable of being nappy. Maybe frizzy and tangled, but not 
nappy!"﻿
comments.author: Jailyn Feliz

comments.text:
I hate it when my mom says " your hair looks tangled go brush it" when I 
already brushed it or "your hair is a mess you can't go out of the house 
like that!" UGHHH﻿

I got soo curly hair and living in Taiwan usually people ask me if it was

comments.text:
I prefer natural hair, they all look fabulous! Keep it up girls! I'm glad

comments.text: Natural hair looks so nice like that though﻿

comments.text: Story of MY life﻿
comments.author: Najee A. (naje3)

comments.text:
Why can't black hair be referred to as black hair or at least natural black 
hair. Why is it just "natural hair/" That's too vague, all races have 
natural hair.﻿
comments.author: Rita M (Schatze)

comments.text:
+Rita M this is not about languages, many things that we say don't 
represent the literal meaning of things. Yes natural hair means hair that 
is natural but because black women often have perms, wear weaves, wigs etc. 
we choose to say natural hair when our hair has not been treated chemically 
and is in its natural state, now white people and other races don't usually 
perm their hair and they dont wear weaves that much therefore they don't 
need to precise that they have their natural hair. We have to precise it 
and unlike you, if I'm looking for hairstyles on youtube I can't just write 
'hair' because I will find many videos of white girls doing their hair or 
others of tutorials for weaves etc while if I write natural hair, I will 
find people who make videos for hair texture like me. And like I said, you 
can say that you have natural hair if you want to it's not only limited to 
black girls but again if you go around saying that you have natural hair, 
you might sound stupid because you don't need to precise that you have 
natural hair.
comments.author: Flo1 Tedruog

comments.text:
+Flo1 Tedruog
A term like "natural" can't be claimed by a group of people. That's not how 
languages work. Natural hair, means having hair that is natural, nothing 
else. There is no other association. "it's like you're trying to be part of 
something that you are not part of." No I'm going to call my hair "natural" 
because my hair is natural not because I want to be black. I'm actually 
using an adjective correctly. Anyone who doesn't have unnatural hair has 
natural hair. Most people going to associate the word natural with black 
people, because that is not what it means. That is like saying Healthy body 
means Asian body.
comments.author: Rita M (Schatze)

comments.text:
Anyways I won't argue with you but all I can say is that natural hair is a 
term that black women use to identify their hair and this term won't change 
just because you don't agree with it, if you go around telling people that 
you have natural hair it's your problem, you will just sound dumb because 
it's like you're trying to be part of something that you are not part of.
comments.author: Flo1 Tedruog

comments.text:
+Flo1 Tedruog
Most hair that hasn't been altered is "natural hair." This term shouldn't 
be applied to any specific race. I have natural hair, I don't have black 
hair.
comments.author: Rita M (Schatze)

comments.text:
+Rita M natural black hair would be the same as natural hair, since it 
would mean someone with natural black hair and then other people would be 
like '' not only black women have natural black hair'' and etc. For it to 
be precise it would have to be natural black women hair but that's just too 
long. And frankly, the term natural hair shouldn't bother anyone, if you 
don't understand it just look it up on google and you'll clearly see what 
natural hair is.
comments.author: Flo1 Tedruog

comments.text:
You know. I never do any of the hairstyles I see her. It looks like too 
much work. ﻿

admit I feel the same, that's why im glad I take looks from my foreign 
side.﻿

I asked my friend what offends her when people ask bout her hair,pretty

comments.text: Now do one on people who don't like to be touched.﻿
comments.author: Kimberly Motas

comments.text: No.﻿
comments.author: Am I right ladies?

comments.text:
Things people tell me: "Oh my God! Your hair is so big! Is it a wig?"
"Do you ever wash your hair? It's oily!" ( and here I have to keep 
repeating that I use a lot of hair conditioners)
"You hair looks so soft and fluffy! Can I touch it?"
"Can I pull your hair a little bit? Just to see if you feel the pain and if 
it's eventually yours"
"Oh my God you look so Afro exotic!"
"Have you ever straightened your hair?"
"Is your hair always this curly?"
Some people just touch my hair even without asking.
"Is your hair always this puffy?"
"I envy you so much! Please give me your hair?"
"Can you comb your hair or the brush gets stuck in it?"
"You look like...." An then they mention a comedian with a big hair.
"Wow you're so wild!"
And it goes on and on.
Weird thing is also when I get in the bus and until I come down, no one 
stops staring at my hair.
Like seriously people, it's just hair. It takes all of my whole patience 
not to slap the hell out of some people who just won't stop with some 
rude/odd questions or that just randomly touches my hair WITHOUT asking. I 
mean, it's not your hair... Is it? Even if you want to touch, have the 
courtesy to ASK. And again, to all of you who are amazed by I don't know 
what... IT'S JUST HAIR. So if you ever see a black girl, a mixed girl with 
natural hair, just remember that YES, we do wash our hair and YES, we do 
comb it. Just like you white girls have hair and you wash, comb it and do 
stuff with it, WE DO THE SAME. ﻿
comments.author: Lana rey Diaz

comments.text: Preech.﻿

comments.text:
Just fyi,the way non african-people sing the zulu part of the circle of

comments.text: I wish I can get my hair into an afro

comments.text: I have natural hair and my hair is straight

comments.text: Running? You think i'm running my hands through it?﻿
comments.author: MissyChuckie

comments.text: 1:30 i strongly agree with this one. my hair is really damn curly.﻿
comments.author: Mr Linda

comments.text: So accurate ﻿
comments.author: Jade Braggs

comments.text:
I have a lot of hair, it's really curly and thick. I got it from my mom's 
side, she's from Mexico. Ever since I was little, people would always touch 
it and say things like:
"Why is it so poufy?"
"It's so poufy!"
"Why do you have so much hair?"
And the boys would tease my friend and I because we didn't have hair like 
the other girls in our class. So now I never wear my hair down, I always 
have it braided or in a bun, not even in a ponytail because I'm always 
afraid of someone touching it or commenting on it. The word "poufy" offends 
me so much. And it really pisses me off when my friends with naturally 
straight and thin hair complain and say they're having a bad day or their 
hair is all "poufy".  They don't even know the struggle. It takes me like 2 
hours to straighten my hair because I have so much. And I can't even manage 
to do it on my own! This one boy would always grab at my bun and squeeze at 
it, the same to my friend. No matter how many times we'd tell him to stop, 
he would continue to touch us. If we'd push him away or get real mad, he'd 
get all offended and everyone would see us as cold bitches.﻿
comments.author: TTayTGER

comments.text:
I'm mixed and I have dreads and it's literally so annoying like don't touch 
me you orangoutangs﻿
comments.author: Destiny Martin

comments.text:
I wear my hair naturally and never straighten it or try to change it. In 
year 3, I would get so mad because my maths teacher used to walk past me 
and my sister, pull a strand of our hair and near enough shout "PING!" at 
the top of her voice. It drove 8 year old me insane! My school was really 
weird about my hair and it really pissed me off. I was even told in year 6 
(11, last year before high school in the UK) ,after the auditions for the 
wizard of oz, by my music teacher " Don't worry Mia. I know you really 
wanted Dorothy, but we only chose you as the lion because your hair is so 
wild. You don't even need a costume, just wear your hair down!" Of course I 
still played the lion (and slayed btw) but this really stuck with me. I 
HATE when people say anything about my hair now. I'm confident with it for 
the most part but as soon as anyone says anything like "your hair is just 
so frizzy" or "can I touch it?" I scrape it up sooner than you can say 
Afro. I wish people would realise that it's old. I've heard it 1000000s of 
times before even from my family. Sorry for this long rant, people just get 
on my nerves sometimes x.﻿
comments.author: Mia Allen

comments.text:
"Have you ever straightened your hair before?" is literally the worst 
question because like, why do you ask? Do you want me to convert to your 
beauty standards, do you have a problem with my hair? I don't ask you if 
you've curled your hair before either.﻿
comments.author: SSiso1

comments.text:
I cannot STAND when people ask me (since I have long hair) "Is your hair a 
weave"? It's like, "Uh no, I have no tracks as you can see and (for the 
people who have seen my with long hair for months) You know my hair is not 
a weave because it is always long" . Or then when they touch it and when I 
slap their hands away they get mad. Eurgh﻿
comments.author: Emerson Rosenberg

comments.text:
I don't mind people touching my hair, but it is awkward. Like what am I 
supposed to do in that situation?﻿
comments.author: Muneira Jibril

comments.text:
I remember when I was going through a phase where I would straighten my 
wild hair every day!﻿
comments.author: Muneira Jibril

comments.text:
UGH I cant stand when people tell me I'd look better with straight hair 
instead of "Curly/Nappy/Kinky/Messy" Hair
Like really?
I love my voluminous natural curls <3﻿
comments.author: Cassie The Larper

comments.text: so true lol﻿
comments.author: Diya Malik

comments.text:
I've had strangers in class get their hands stuck in my hair when sitting

comments.text: stright hair is still natural you have to chemically change it﻿

comments.text:
when they go :" oh wow !!! it's actually so softttt omg..." like it's

comments.author: GreenSuugar

comments.text:
Do you mean all women withg natural curly hair? Because I have natural 
straight hair and none of these have happened to me.﻿
comments.author: Kassidy Wiskari

comments.text:
This kind of annoys me, because it says things women with natural hair are 
tired of hearing. The problem I have with it, is that not all women who 
wear their hair natural, or have natural hair (i.e. don't wear wigs) have 
hair like that. I think they are missing a modifier.﻿
comments.author: Elizabeth Alicia

comments.text:
I'm white, but I've naturally got really weird, curly and bent up hair. I 
like to wear it naturally as well. I don't get the "can I touch your hair" 
or other annoying comments I'm sure a lot of black girls have to deal with 
(which sounds so aggravating - sorry to the ladies who have to deal with 
those dicks) but the scene with the mom? Oh my God. Constantly, "what are 
you gonna do to your hair? Remember when you used to straighten it? No 
one's gonna take you seriously with crazy bed head." It's endless.﻿
comments.author: Keyanna Mars

comments.text: Better that good-looking hair than the SUPER OILY straighten...﻿

comments.text:
"it's so unique and exotic"... i wouldn't care is someone says that to

I hear the same stuff all the time even though I'm white xD My hair's

comments.text:
Yeah like this guy yesterday kept smelling my hair? I felt intruded but I

comments.author: Monica Windom

comments.text:
i would just like for people to stop telling me i should straighten my 
hair, i'm mixed and have very thick curly hair and people say that to me 
all the time. it's annoying, this is what i look like and just because 
something is different doesn't mean it's bad. please don't make curly hair 
something anyone should change about themselves, not everyone was meant to 
have straight hair.﻿
comments.author: Jenna Holt

comments.text: do you wash your hair? if i hear that one more time i might explode﻿
comments.author: alexjd10291

comments.text: Not all girls with naturally curly hair are African American.﻿
comments.author: Ray Browning
